bestBHT.bht: This is Jesus of Nazareth the King of the Jews. Luke mentions the title later than the other Evangelists; the sneer of the soldiers suggested the mention of Pilate’s mockery in writing this superscription. The full title appeared in Latin for law, in Aramaic for the Jews, in Greek for everybody. Matthew 27:37; Mark 15:26; John 19:19.

Put all the reports together and we have: This is Jesus of Nazareth the King of the Jews.
John Gill: And a superscription also was written,.... Containing the crime he was charged with, and accused of;

bhtAttempts.bht: This is Jesus of Nazareth the King of the Jews. This full title appeared in Latin for law, in Aramaic for the Jews, in Greek for everybody. See on Matthew, ver. 37. over him, on the projecting upright beam of the cross. Luke mentions the title later than the other Evangelists; the sneer of the soldiers suggested the mention of Pilate’s mockery in writing this superscription. Matthew 27:37; Mark 15:26; John 19:19.

This is Jesus of Nazareth the King of the Jews. Luke mentions the title later than the other Evangelists; the sneer of the soldiers suggested the mention of Pilate’s mockery in writing this superscription. The full title appeared in Latin for law, in Aramaic for the Jews, in Greek for everybody. Matthew 27:37; Mark 15:26; John 19:19.

On the beam of the cross, there was a superscription that read, This is Jesus of Nazareth the King of the Jews. Luke includes this detail later than the other Evangelists, perhaps to highlight the soldiers' sneering mockery facilitated by Pilate's order to write this inscription. The full title was displayed in multiple languages - Latin, Aramaic, and Greek - ensuring that it was understood by all. This verse can be further explored in Matthew 27:37, Mark 15:26, and John 19:19.

This is Jesus of Nazareth the King of the Jews, states the superscription placed on the upright beam of the cross. Luke includes this detail later than the other Evangelists, suggesting a mocking tone from the soldiers. Pilate's order to write the inscription in Latin, Aramaic, and Greek ensured that it was understood by all. For more information, see Matthew 27:37, Mark 15:26, and John 19:19.

The superscription on the cross declares, This is Jesus of Nazareth the King of the Jews. Luke's account includes this detail later than the other Evangelists, likely highlighting the soldiers' mocking and Pilate's order to inscribe this title. The full title appeared in Latin, Aramaic, and Greek to ensure its comprehension by everyone. For further understanding, see Matthew 27:37, Mark 15:26, and John 19:19.
